se.softhouse.jargo

Class Usage

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.softhouse.jargo.Usage
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    @NotThreadSafe
public final class Usage
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Responsible for formatting usage texts for CommandLineParser.usage() and Arguments.helpArgument(String, String...). Using it is often as simple as: 
     
 System.out.print(CommandLineParser.withArguments(someArguments).usage());
 
 
     Sorts Arguments in the following order:
 
      
   
    1. indexed arguments without a variable arity
      2. 
         
    2. By their first name  in an alphabetical order
      3. 
         
    3. The remaining indexed arguments that are of variable arity
      4.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void printOn(Appendable target)
      Appends usage to target.
      void printOn(PrintStream target)
      Appends usage to target, just like printOn(Appendable) but for a PrintStream instead.
      void printOn(StringBuilder target)
      Appends usage to target, just like printOn(Appendable) but for a StringBuilder instead
      String toString()
      Returns the usage text that's suitable to print on System.out.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns the usage text that's suitable to print on System.out.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object

      • printOn

        public void printOn(Appendable target)
             throws IOException
        Appends usage to target. An alternative to toString() when the usage is very large and needs to be flushed from time to time.
        Throws:
        IOException - If an I/O error occurs while appending usage

      • printOn

        public void printOn(PrintStream target)
        Appends usage to target, just like printOn(Appendable) but for a PrintStream instead. The reason for this overload is that Appendable declares IOException to be thrown while PrintStream handles it internally through the use of the PrintStream.checkError() method.
        Parameters:
        target - a PrintStream such as System.out or System.err.

      • printOn

        public void printOn(StringBuilder target)
        Appends usage to target, just like printOn(Appendable) but for a StringBuilder instead
